access.description: The registered URL (https://medisolv.com/certifications) is a HubSpot-hosted static HTML page that loads cleanly via curl with no anti-bot issues. The certifications page contains a list of compliance documents (certificates, real-world testing plans/results) and at the bottom, a link labeled 'EHI Export Format: 170.315(b)(10)' pointing to /ehiexport. That page is also a static HubSpot page that loads cleanly. No accordion navigation, no JavaScript rendering required, no special headers needed.

products.name: ENCOR-e

product_context.description: ENCOR-e is NOT a full EHR. It is a specialized clinical quality measure (eCQM) reporting and quality management platform. Medisolv describes it as 'Electronic Measures software designed to assist hospitals and clinicians in monitoring, improving and reporting their eCQMs to CMS and other regulatory bodies.' It is a secondary/downstream system that ingests a subset of clinical data from a customer's primary EHR (Epic, Cerner, MEDITECH, Allscripts, etc.) via nightly incremental data loads, computes quality measures, and reports results to CMS, The Joint Commission, and other regulatory bodies. It has no patient portal, no billing, no scheduling, no document management — only quality-measure-relevant clinical data elements. The CHPL certification confirms this: no (a)-series clinical data criteria, no (e)(1) patient portal, no (f)-series public health, no (g)(7)-(g)(10) FHIR APIs — only (b)(10) EHI export, (c)(1)-(c)(3) clinical quality measures, and (d)-series security/privacy criteria.

export_approach.description: ENCOR-e exports EHI as QRDA-I (Quality Reporting Document Architecture - Category I) XML documents, an HL7 CDA R2 standard designed for quality measure reporting. Each document contains patient demographics, clinical data elements relevant to quality measures (diagnoses, procedures, medications, lab results), and encounter information. This is a standard-format export — not a native database dump. Single patient export is available via a UI button ('QRDA Export (Full Record)') on the patient detail page. Bulk export requires contacting a Medisolv Clinical Quality Advisor, who initiates the process and delivers via secure email or SFTP. The vendor provides no proprietary data dictionary — they defer entirely to the HL7 QRDA-I specification.

documentation_quality.description: Documentation is minimal: a single web page with a few paragraphs describing the export process, an embedded screenshot of the ENCOR-e UI showing the export button, and a link to the HL7 QRDA-I standard specification ZIP. There is no vendor-specific data dictionary, no field-level mapping, no sample files, and no documentation of which ENCOR-e data elements map to which QRDA-I sections. The vendor effectively says 'we export QRDA-I, go read the QRDA-I spec.'

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: ENCOR-e is a quality reporting tool, not a full EHR, so its data footprint is inherently limited to quality-measure-relevant clinical data elements. The QRDA-I export likely covers most of what the product stores (demographics, diagnoses, procedures, medications, labs, encounters), which is the correct scope for b(10) compliance — the requirement is 'all EHI stored by the product.' However, the product stores only a small fraction of what a full EHR would store. Non-clinical categories (billing, messaging, scheduling, documents) are absent because the product simply doesn't manage that data. The export is likely adequate for the product's narrow scope, but the QRDA-I format may not capture all internal data (e.g., abstracted chart data, quality measure calculation results, internal notes) that ENCOR-e stores beyond the standard QRDA-I data elements.

clinical.evidence: QRDA-I export contains patient demographics, diagnoses, procedures, medications, lab results, and encounter information — the clinical data elements ENCOR-e ingests from upstream EHRs for quality measure computation. Limited to eCQM-relevant data elements, not a comprehensive clinical record.

secure_messages.evidence: ENCOR-e has no messaging or patient portal functionality. It does not store patient-provider communications. This is not a gap — the product simply doesn't handle messages.

billing_financial.evidence: ENCOR-e has no billing, claims, or financial management functionality. It does not store billing data. Not a gap relative to the product's scope.

insurance_coverage.evidence: ENCOR-e does not store insurance or coverage information. Not a gap relative to the product's scope.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: ENCOR-e does not store scheduling data. Encounter dates are present in QRDA-I exports, but appointment/scheduling management is not part of the product. Not a gap relative to the product's scope.

documents_images.evidence: ENCOR-e does not store scanned documents, images, or attachments. Not a gap relative to the product's scope.

issues: QRDA-I is a quality reporting format, not a comprehensive EHI export format. While it covers the clinical data elements ENCOR-e stores for eCQM computation, it may not capture all internal data the product stores (e.g., quality measure calculation results, abstracted chart data, internal annotations, performance analytics data).

No vendor-specific data dictionary or field mapping. The only format documentation is a link to the HL7 QRDA-I standard spec — no documentation of which ENCOR-e fields map to which QRDA-I elements or what data may be excluded.
Full system export is not self-service. Users must contact a Medisolv Clinical Quality Advisor to request a bulk export, creating a dependency on vendor availability.
Documentation is extremely minimal — a single web page with a few paragraphs and no technical detail beyond pointing to the QRDA-I standard.
products.summary: ENCOR-e is a quality reporting tool (not a full EHR) that exports via QRDA-I XML. The export likely covers most of the product's limited data scope (quality-measure-relevant clinical data), but the documentation is minimal — a single web page with no vendor-specific data dictionary — and full system export requires vendor assistance.

downloaded_files.description: The complete EHI export documentation page for ENCOR-e, containing export process description, UI screenshot, and link to QRDA-I specification.
Full-page screenshot of the EHI export documentation page, showing the embedded UI screenshot with the QRDA Export button.

summary: Medisolv's ENCOR-e is a specialized quality reporting tool (not a full EHR) that exports EHI as QRDA-I XML documents. The export documentation is minimal — a single web page pointing to the HL7 QRDA-I standard — with no vendor-specific data dictionary. The product's narrow scope (only quality-measure-relevant clinical data) means the export likely covers what it stores, but that scope is a small fraction of full EHI. Full system export requires contacting the vendor.
notes: ENCOR-e's certified criteria profile ((b)(10), (c)(1)-(c)(3), (d)-series, (g)(2)/(g)(4)/(g)(5) only) is a strong indicator that this is a quality reporting tool, not a clinical system. The absence of (a)-series, (e)-series, (f)-series, and (g)(7)-(g)(10) criteria confirms the product does not handle direct clinical data capture, patient portals, public health reporting, or FHIR API access. The QRDA-I export format is well-suited for quality measure data but may not capture all internal product data (abstracted measures, quality scores, performance analytics). The HL7 QRDA-I specification ZIP linked from the page (https://www.hl7.org/documentcenter/public/standards/dstu/CDAR2_IG_QRDA_I_R1_STU5.3_2021NOV_2022DEC_with_errata.zip) is a standard spec, not vendor-specific documentation.
